conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand how liquids move through the baffles and then determine which container they will flow into based on their direction.
Orange liquid flows down vertically from A.
White liquid flows down diagonally from B.
Blue liquid flows down diagonally from C.
Yellow liquid flows down diagonally from D.
The orange liquid from A flows downward and hits the blue baffle. It will be deflected by the blue baffle but still continue downward.
The white liquid from B flows diagonally downward and gets deflected by the red baffle. The deflection is upward and slightly to the right.
The blue liquid from C flows diagonally downward and gets deflected by the red baffle. The deflection is upward and slightly to the left.
The yellow liquid from D flows diagonally downward and gets deflected by the red baffle. The deflection is upward and slightly to the left.
The orange liquid from A continues downward and ultimately flows into the red container F.
The white liquid from B, after being deflected, moves upward and crosses over the blue baffle, then it will flow into the red container F.
The blue liquid from C, after being deflected, moves upward and crosses over the red baffle, then it will flow into the red container F.
The yellow liquid from D, after being deflected, moves upward and crosses over the red baffle, then it will flow into the red container F.
All the liquids (orange, white, blue, and yellow) from A, B, C, and D will flow into the same container, which is the red container F.
Final Answer: The liquids from A, B, C, and D will flow into the red container (F).
